column9: The candidate outlined a clear and compelling vision for the future of WIHR.
column10: The candidate demonstrated an understanding of the local and national Humanities landscape.
column11: The candidate was prepared and organized.
column12: The presentation was concise and well-structured.
column13: The candidate offered concrete examples and strategies for WIHR.
column15: Overall, I would rate this presentation as:
column16: What parts of this vision resonate with you and would best move WIHR forward? (please explain)
column17: What parts of this vision do you find unattainable or disagree with? (please explain)
column18: Do you have any ideas about possible WIHR activities not covered in the talk but you would like to pass along?

column16: As someone who is not in a traditional humanities discipline, I do find the idea of increased cross-collaborations across campus encouraging
column17: I don't know that it's necessarily unattainable, but her suggestions about developing all of these internal grants without a clear idea of where that money would come from seems somewhat unrealistic.
column18: I would like to see a humanities "interest group" similarly to how the Science Initiative is creating centers around certain topics

column16: Expanding grants, encouraging student engagement
column17: Relying so heavily on the fellows and themes

column16: I think the idea of supporting faculty to find and apply for national grants, etc. was compelling.
column17: I would have liked to see a more concrete vision for the budget.

column16: Melissa's vision for collaboration with campus partners is essential for moving WIHR forward. Particularly discussing DH and collaborating with the libraries, School of Computing, etc.
column17: Not that it's unattainable, but opportunities for obtaining humanities grants are becoming sparse due to federal cuts. I would have loved to hear about alternative funding sources besides NEH.
column21: Based on the presentation, Melissa is a passionate advocate for the humanities and has a strong awareness of emerging research trends in the humanities.

column16: I actually believe she should’ve defended her vision more for the yearly theme. I think themes sometimes get people to stretch their interests or scope of their work.
I think having WIHR apply for additional grants, the suggestion to have smaller events for faculty to network, and advertising events in the Boomerang were great ideas.
column17: I think it's all doable. Most of the suggestions were low or no cost.
column21: Dr. Morris is an experienced "grant getter" and an outstanding candidate for the job.

column16: Student involvement would allow WIHR to help with fostering a broader humanities ecosystem on campus and potentially help with its fundraising efforts.
column17: Centering changes on the Humanities Research group. There should be new developments beyond this program, rather than changes to something already running well.
column20: The candidate did not present much of a vision beyond the infrastructure already in place.
column21: The candidate had the advantage of attending the Humanities Retreat but their presentation did not reflect the complexity and vitality of the discussion that happened there.

column16: Bringing humanities research to other places in the state so Wyoming citizens can understand and appreciate the work that is done by UW.
column17: None

column16: Proactive digital humanities work for democratization of information, faith in UW's ability to produce preeminent scholars, & understanding of the need for access to the humanities across the state.
column17: None

column16: A clear agenda and ideas moving forward that are exciting in terms of fellowships and vision.
column17: The presentation was excellent, but as a person, this candidate is exclusionary. There is a level of elitism that is not inviting, but rather isolating, and it smacks of "my PhD is better than yours."
column18: There must be a focus on diversity as central in all of WIHR's component. This organization has not been good about getting rid of the stuffy Renaissance Salon vibe
column20: See #8. Reservations in terms of colleaguality.

column16: Much of Melissa's vision aligned with discussions we had at the Humanities retreat - so she wisely came to understand the consensus of the faculty and geared her presentation accordingly.
column17: I'm not certain that theming all of the Institute's work in a given year around a specific theme is wise - some events can operate this way, but we need to cast a wide net in terms of involvement.

column16: Reaching out to the broader community and involving them in humanities orientated talks/events
column17: I'm not sure even the themes will always have the broadest appeal and might exclude some people
column21: Dr. Morris seems like a great candidate with lots of great ideas that can make WIHR much more significant within UW and a leader among humanities organizations

column16: The yearly themes and an invited Post-Doc
I particularly liked the idea of broadening what we think of as the humanities and promoting the work of WIHR as inclusive and accessible.
column17: In light of the decimation of NEH, I thought the ramifications of this major change should have been addressed in more depth.
column21: It's a little hard to answer the previous question if you're asking people if they would recommend a particular candidate for the position before we've heard from the 2nd candidate.

column16: increased community involvement; student involvement
I liked the emphasis on WIHR as a location where events from all over can be supported and advertised. I also like the focus on grant writing and on seeing humanities as both local and global.
column17: Her vision is attainable.
column20: My concern is this candidate can be cliquish and treat some humanities colleagues with disregard. Her attitude can appear snobbish and exclusive. I hope she'd be more mindful as WIHR director.

column17: Given the nature of funding for the humanities these days -- and for the next few years -- I would have appreciated a more realistic presentation of what is possible re. external funding from granting
column18: I wish I had heard more ideas about connecting with the communities of national/international humanities institutes.

column16: Leveraging the existing strengths of humanities research at UW.
column17: n/a
column18: Perhaps more discussion of how to involve the Neltje Center.

column20: Not experienced enough, too History focused

column16: Great ideas in terms of big picture, but also small details that would really matter. Theme based approach is intriguing.
column17: There are some aspects of the theme based approach that might need to be ironed out, but it’s a good idea.

column16: Both candidates would make good leaders, but given that Morris just recently earned tenure and Sailor is a full professor, I think Sailor is the best choice for Director. Morris should be Assist. Dir.
column21: Both candidates would make good leaders, but given that Morris just recently earned tenure and Sailor is a full professor, I think Sailor is the best choice for Director. Morris should be Assist. Dir.

column16: I liked all of their ideas and enthusiasm for the position.
Broad vision for the Humanities' importance to the university, the state, and the world
column17: n/a
column18: It will be important to choose the annual themes carefully and in consultation with relevant communities on campus in order to ensure broad participation from different disciplines and subfields
column21: For this position, I think it is more important to have a younger and more dynamic researcher than a more senior scholar with more administrative experience

column16: Good ideas regarding annual themes and inviting multiple speakers instead of targeting one expensive speaker or one favorite topic year after year.
column17: I was pleased with all parts of the vision.
column18: Use the Stockgrower's Room at AHC for special events programming and take the "show on the road" to other Wyo communities that can benefit from WIHR's programming.
column21: Superb candidate, I have no reservations whatsoever about having Melissa Morris as director of WIHR

column16: I really appreciated her ideas for 1) faculty research cohorts and 2) international outreach. These should be priorities for our institution, and Dr. Morris can make them happen!
column21: Dr. Morris is an exceptional candidate for this position. She hails from a department that is deeply involved in numerous activities on campus and will bring a wealth of energy to the position.

column16: Melissa gave an ambitious program for WIHR that would position it to catalyze humanities research. Building on strengths, outlining themes/building programming, and grant cultivation strategies.
column17: I do not disagree with any part of this presentation. Bringing in those who are not currently friendly to the humanities per one question would be difficult but important.
column18: I like her approach to including those not currently in the fellows group - this has been a major limitation of WIHR for the past 5 years.
column21: Melissa beautifully connected her own experience and research to her vision for how to position WIHR as an entity to encourage excellence. She's a poster child for UW's ability to cultivate excellence

column16: I thought the idea of yearly themes as well as recurring programming was compelling, and offers a way for the humanities community to build as well as sustain momentum.
column17: n/a
